Chapter 7 State-space models This section describes how to specify a state-space model (SSM) in an ilike file. An SSM describes the evolution of an indirectly observed latent “state” variable over time. We denote the state at time \(t\) as \(x_t\) and the observation at time \(t\) as \(y_t\). A Markov assumption is made on the state, so that the distribution of \(x_t\) depends only on \(x_{t-1}\). A further conditional independence assumption is made that \(y_t\) is conditionally independent of all other variables in the system given \(x_t\). The distribution of \(x_t\) given \(x_{t-1}\) is known as the transition/dynamic model, with the distribution of \(y_t\) given \(x_t\) being known as the measurement/observation model. The specification of a joint distribution over variables \(x_{0:T}\) and \(y_{0:T}\), for some final time \(T\) is completed by a prior on \(x_0\), the initial state. To specify this model in an ilike file, we need to provide the following: The prior on the initial state \(x_0\). This can be provided using the methods described for providing a prior in section 4. The measurement model on \(y_t \mid x_t\). This can be provided using the methods described for providing a likelihood in section 4. If multiple likelihoods are provided, the distribution of the observed variables in each likelihood will be assumed to be conditionally independent given \(x_t\). The transition model on \(x_t \mid x_{t-1}\). This can be provided using the methods described in this section. Several different types of inference tasks are specific to SSMs: e.g. filtering, smoothing and prediction of the latent state. ilike currently only supports filtering, including Kalman, particle and ensemble Kalman filtering. In order to use these algorithms on real data, sometimes additional details are required, such as the sampling frequency of the data. These details must be provided through the ssm function type, which we describe in this section. To use a particle filter, the user also needs to provide a transition proposal, for propagating the set of particles at each iteration. If this is not provided, the transition model will be used as the proposal, yielding the bootstrap filter of Gordon, Salmond, and Smith (1993). A description of how to provide the transition proposal is provided after the sections on transition models. References Gordon, Neil J, David J Salmond, and Adrian FM Smith. 1993. “Novel Approach to Nonlinear/Non-Gaussian Bayesian State Estimation.” In IEE Proceedings f (Radar and Signal Processing), 140:107–13. 2. IET.

7.1 State-space supporting detail This section describes how to provide the supporting detail to “wrap” a SSM for use in a filtering or smoothing algorithm. 7.1.1 ssm The ssm function type is used to wrap a SSM, providing the information required to link it to data and use it in a filtering or smoothing algorithm. 7.1.1.1 SSM wrapper ilike::ssm This function is used for, amongst other things, to setup variables that refer to the index and time stamp of the state. This can then be used as part of a transition model for example - to set up a model that has a time-dependent transition kernel. Inputs: string: the name of the variable that indexes the SSM, i.e the \(t\) in the \(x_t\) from above integer: the first index in the SSM, i.e. the \(0\) in the \(x_0\) from above integer: the last index in the SSM, i.e. the \(T\) in the \(x_T\) from above string: the name of the variable that corresponds to the time stamps in the observed data. This need not be the same as the variable that indexes the SSM: this may be useful if the sampling frequency of the data is not 1 numeric: the time of the first observation string: the name of the variable that corresponds to the time difference between observations (again, this may be useful if the sampling frequency is not 1) numeric: the time step between states in the SSM integer: the number of times to use the transition model between observations (you may wish this to be greater than 1 when the transition model is an SDE solver with a small time step)

7.2 Linear-Gaussian transition model The linear-Gaussian transition model subtype may be used to specify a transition model in a state-space model that consists of a linear function of the state, plus some Gaussian noise, i.e. \[ x_t \sim \mathcal{N}(A x_{t-1}, Q) \tag{7.1} \] where \(A\) is a matrix and \(Q\) is a covariance matrix. To specify the model we need to provide the state name (\(x\) here), the matrix \(A\) and the matrix \(Q\). There are two ways of specifying a linear-Gaussian data model: Through the function types linear_gaussian_transition_variable (specifying the name of the \(x\) variable), linear_gaussian_transition_matrix (specifying the \(A\) matrix), and linear_gaussian_transition_covariance (specifying the name of the \(Q\) matrix), The user needs to provide all of these functions in order to fully specify the model. Through the function type linear_gaussian_transition_model, which allows the user to specify the complete model through an ilike function. We now detail the function types. 7.2.1 linear_gaussian_transition_variable Specifies the name of the observed transition variable in the linear-Gaussian transition model. There are no input arguments. Output: The name of the variable used as \(x\) in equation (7.1). – of type const std::string & in a C++ function – a string in R. C++ example: /***linear_gaussian_transition_variable***/ std::string set_transition_variable() { return "x"; } R example: /***linear_gaussian_transition_variable,"x"***/ 7.2.2 linear_gaussian_transition_matrix Specifies the matrix \(A\) in the linear-Gaussian transition model. Input (optional): Parameters that the matrix relies on, to allow the specification of a parameter-dependent matrix. – of type const Parameters & in a C++ function – available as R list parameters in an R function Output: The matrix \(A\) in equation (7.1). – of type arma::mat in a C++ function – a matrix in R. C++ examples: /***linear_gaussian_transition_matrix***/ arma::mat set_matrix() { arma::mat A(2,2); A(0,0) = 1.0; A(0,1) = 0.0; A(1,0) = 0.0; A(1,1) = 1.0; return A; } or /***linear_gaussian_transition_matrix***/ arma::mat set_matrix(const Parameters &parameters) { double scale = parameters["scale"][0]; arma::mat A(2,2); A(0,0) = scale; A(0,1) = 0.0; A(1,0) = 0.0; A(1,1) = scale; return A; } R example: /***linear_gaussian_transition_matrix,diag(2)***/ or /***linear_gaussian_transition_matrix,parameters$scale*diag(2)***/ 7.2.3 linear_gaussian_transition_covariance Specifies the covariance matrix \(Q\) in the linear-Gaussian transition model. Input (optional): Parameters that the matrix relies on, to allow the specification of a parameter-dependent matrix. – of type const Parameters & in a C++ function – available as R list parameters in an R function Output: The covariance matrix \(Q\) in equation (7.1). – of type arma::mat in a C++ function – a matrix in R C++ examples: /***linear_gaussian_transition_covariance***/ arma::mat set_covariance() { arma::mat Q(2,2); Q(0,0) = 1.0; Q(0,1) = 0.0; Q(1,0) = 0.0; Q(1,1) = 1.0; return Q; } or /***linear_gaussian_transition_covariance***/ arma::mat set_covariance(const Parameters &parameters) { double scale = parameters["scale"][0]; arma::mat Q(2,2); Q(0,0) = scale; Q(0,1) = 0.0; Q(1,0) = 0.0; Q(1,1) = scale; return Q; } R examples: /***linear_gaussian_transition_covariance,diag(2)***/ or /***linear_gaussian_transition_covariance,parameters$scale*diag(2)***/ 7.2.4 linear_gaussian_transition_model We may use an ilike function to specify the complete linear-Gaussian transition model. 7.2.4.1 Linear-Gaussian transition model ilike::linear_gaussian_transition_model Specifies the linear-Gaussian transition model. Inputs: string: The name of the observed transition variable string: The name of the latent state variable matrix: The matrix \(A\) matrix: The covariance matrix \(Q\)

7.3 Nonlinear-Gaussian transition model The nonlinear-Gaussian transition model subtype may be used to specify a model where the state \(x_t\) has a Gaussian distribution where the mean depends nonlinearly on \(x_{t-1}\), plus some Gaussian noise, i.e. \[ x_t \sim \mathcal{N}(g(x_{t-1}), Q) \tag{7.2} \] where \(g\) is a function and \(Q\) is a covariance matrix. To specify the model we need to provide the variable name (\(x\)), the function \(g\) and the matrix \(Q\). To do this the user must provide three function types, respectively: nonlinear_gaussian_transition_variable, nonlinear_gaussian_transition_function and nonlinear_gaussian_transition_covariance. 7.3.1 nonlinear_gaussian_transition_variable Specifies the name of the observed transition variable. There are no input arguments. Output: The name of the observed transition variable. – of type const std::string & in a C++ function – a string in R. C++ example: /***nonlinear_gaussian_transition_variable***/ std::string set_variable() { return "x"; } R example: /***nonlinear_gaussian_transition_variable,"x"***/ 7.3.2 nonlinear_gaussian_transition_function Specifies the function \(g\) in the nonlinear-Gaussian transition model. Input: The state \(x\) and any parameters that the function relies on (the latter may be included to allow the specification of a parameter-dependent function) – of type const Parameters & in a C++ function – available as R list parameters in an R function Output: The output of the function \(g\) in equation (7.2). – of type const Parameters & in a C++ function – a list in R. C++ example: /***nonlinear_gaussian_transition_function***/ Parameters transform_state(const Parameters &xtminus1_and_theta) { arma::colvec noiseless_xt(1,1); noiseless_xt[0] = exp(xtminus1_and_theta["x"][0) + xtminus1_and_theta["theta"][0]; return Parameters("x", noiseless_xt); } R example: /***nonlinear_gaussian_transition_function,x=exp(parameters$x)+parameters$theta***/ 7.3.3 nonlinear_gaussian_transition_covariance Specifies the covariance matrix \(Q\) in the nonlinear-Gaussian transition model. Input (optional): Parameters that the matrix relies on, to allow the specification of a parameter-dependent matrix. – of type const Parameters & in a C++ function – available as R list parameters in an R function Output: The covariance matrix \(Q\) in equation (7.2). – of type arma::mat in a C++ function – a matrix in R. C++ examples: /***nonlinear_gaussian_transition_covariance***/ arma::mat set_covariance() { arma::mat Q(2,2); Q(0,0) = 1.0; Q(0,1) = 0.0; Q(1,0) = 0.0; Q(1,1) = 1.0; return Q; } or /***nonlinear_gaussian_transition_covariance***/ arma::mat set_covariance(const Parameters &parameters) { double scale = parameters["scale"][0]; arma::mat Q(2,2); Q,0) = scale; Q(0,1) = 0.0; Q(1,0) = 0.0; Q(1,1) = scale; return Q; } R examples: /***nonlinear_gaussian_transition_covariance,diag(2)***/ or /***nonlinear_gaussian_transition_covariance,parameters$scale*diag(2)***/

7.4 User-defined transition model The functions in this section allow the specification of a user-defined transition model. The two possible function types are simulate_transition_model and evaluate_log_transition_model. Only the functions required by the chosen inference algorithm need be specified: for example, bootstrap particle filter does not need to evaluate the density of the transition model, so this function type does not need to be provided. 7.4.1 simulate_transition model The simulate_transition_model function type simulates the latent state at time \(t\) given the latent state at time \(t-1\) and any parameters that the model relies on. Input: (C++ only) The random number generator. – of type RandomNumberGenerator & in a C++ function Input: The latent state at time \(t-1\) and any parameters that the model relies on. – of type const Parameters & in a C++ function – available as R list parameters in an R function Output: The latent state at time \(t\). – of type const Parameters & in a C++ function – of type list in R C++ example: /***simulate_transition_model***/ Parameters simulate_state(RandomNumberGenerator &rng, const Parameters &xtminus1_and_theta) { arma::colvec xt(1,1); noiseless_xt[0] = rnorm(rng,1,exp(xtminus1_and_theta["x"][0) + xtminus1_and_theta["theta"][0],1.0); return Parameters("x", noiseless_xt); } R example: /***simulate_transition_model,x=rnorm(1,exp(parameters$x)+parameters$theta,1)***/ 7.4.2 evaluate_log_transition_model The evaluate_log_transition_model function type evaluates the log transition density of the latent state at time \(t\) given the latent state at time \(t-1\) and any parameters that the model relies on. Input: The proposed latent state at time \(t\) and any parameters that the model relies on. – of type const Parameters & in a C++ function – available as R list proposed_parameters in an R function Input: The latent state at time \(t-1\) and any parameters that the model relies on. – of type const Parameters & in a C++ function – available as R list parameters in an R function Output: The log transition density of the latent state at time \(t\) given the latent state at time \(t-1\). – of type double in a C++ function – of type numeric in R C++ example: /***evaluate_log_transition_model***/ double log_transition_density(const Parameters &proposed_parameters, const Parameters &parameters) { double x = proposed_parameters["x"][0]; double xminus1 = parameters["x"][0]; double theta = parameters["theta"][0]; return dnorm(x, exp(xminus1) + theta, 1.0); } R example: /***evaluate_log_transition_model,dnorm(parameters$x,exp(parameters$x)+parameters$theta,1,log=TRUE)***/

7.5 Linear-Gaussian transition proposal The linear-Gaussian transition proposal subtype may be used to specify a transition proposal for a particle filter that consists of a linear function of the state, plus some Gaussian noise, i.e. \[ x_t \sim \mathcal{N}(A x_{t-1}, Q) \tag{7.1} \] where \(A\) is a matrix and \(Q\) is a covariance matrix. To specify the proposal we need to provide the state name (\(x\) here), the matrix \(A\) and the matrix \(Q\). Through the function type linear_gaussian_transition_proposal, which allows the user to specify the complete proposal through an ilike function. We now detail the function types. 7.5.1 linear_gaussian_transition_variable Specifies the name of the observed transition variable in the linear-Gaussian transition proposal. There are no input arguments. Output: The name of the variable used as \(x\) in equation (7.1). – of type const std::string & in a C++ function – a string in R.
